awd_titl_txt: UHTC Conference - Ultra-High Temperature Ceramics: Materials for Extreme Environment Applications V
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical abstract

The “Ultra-High Temperature Ceramics: Materials for Extreme Environment Applications V” conference bring together the community of scientist and engineers in Snowbird, UT, in June 2022. The conference is focused on discussing state-of-the-art in ultrahigh temperature ceramic (UHTC) processing, characterization and properties. Given the renewed interest in this field the meeting is very timely and relevant to the ceramics scientific community and plays an important role of research dissemination and fostering scientific collaboration. It provides an ideal environment for junior scientists and engineers to become integrated into the field. Support from the Ceramics Program in the Division of Materials Research enables supporting up to five individuals that are either graduate students, post-doctoral fellows, or early career individuals. Particular attention to supporting individuals from groups that are historically underrepresented in the STEM disciplines is achieved through this travel participant/registration award.


Technical abstract

Ultra-High Temperature Ceramics (UHTCs) - which includes transition metal carbides, nitrides, and borides - are a family of compounds that display a unique set of properties, including extremely high melting temperatures (>3000 deg. C), high hardness and good chemical stability and strength at high temperatures. The combination of properties makes these materials candidates for a variety of high-temperature structural applications, including engines, high-speed vehicles, plasma arc electrodes, cutting tools, and advanced nuclear fuel usages. The conference’s focus on the scientific status of UHTC and the ability for leading experts to share their developments will ensure a continuation of new ideas and nurture collaborations that provide distinct advancements in a class that are ever more relevant to meet the demands placed on materials in extreme environments. The travel award is used to enable graduate, post docs, and/or early professionals, particularly those from underrepresented demographics in STEM, to participate in the conference.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The National Science Foundation (NSF) support went towards offsetting registration and travel expanse fees for graduate students and young professionals (post docs, tenure track assistant professors, etc.) to attend the Ultrahigh Temperature Ceramics (UHTC) ? Materials for extreme environments V meeting.  This conference is nominally held once every three years through the nonprofit Engineering Conferences International series. The aim of this specialized conference is to bring together world experts in this field to discuss state-of-the-art developments as well as develop networking and learning opportunities which includes increasing the integration of a raising generation workforce in UHTCs.  

UHTCs are a family of compounds that display a unique set of properties, including extremely high melting temperatures (>3000 deg. C), high hardness and good chemical stability and strength at elevated temperatures.  The combination of properties makes these materials potential candidates for a variety of high-temperature structural applications, including engines, high-speed vehicles, plasma arc electrodes, advanced nuclear fuels, fusion first walls and divertors, cutting tools, furnace elements and high temperature shielding.

The conference was held June 5-8th 2022 at the Snowbird Lodge in Utah (USA).  This offseason resort allowed the attendees a secluded location, with minimal disruptions, to foster technical discussions through the course of the conference. The conference lead organizers included Drs. Daniel Butts (MACH-20, LLC), Carmen Carney (Air Force Research Laboratory), Carolina Tallon (Virginia Tec), Gregory Thompson (University of Alabama), and Chris Weinberger (Colorado State University). The programming committee also included eight domestic and international professionals in the community. 

Intellectual merit summary:  The conference had 44 oral presentations (contributed and invited talks) and 19 posters that was shared with over 100 registered participants from the USA, Germany, UK, and France to name a few.  Topical areas of the sessions included Processing & Properties; Fundamental Properties; High Entropy Materials; Extreme Environment Testing; Engineered Structures; Near Net Shape Processing; and UHTC-CMCs & Coatings.

Boarder impact summary: The funds provided by NSF and other federal agencies allowed for all 18 graduate students and 2 young professionals to attend. Specifically, NSF supported five students, four of whom are from historically underrepresented demographics in STEM and 1 young professional, who was completing her post-doctoral fellowship at a federal research laboratory. Collectively, the NSF support was successful in increasing the representation and opportunities for these individuals to participate in this unique venue for their professional development.

 


Last Modified: 06/26/2023
Modified by: Gregory B Thompson
